childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1950-1962

The smell of Bactine on scraped knees. The heft of a genuine Davy Crockett coonskin cap. The satisfying click of Lincoln Logs locking into place. Your childhood had a weight to it—everything was made of metal, wood, or genuine leather. Plastic was for poor people.

At four, you were watching Howdy Doody in the living room of a neighbor who had a TV—your family probably didn't own one yet. By six, you had your own set, and Captain Kangaroo became your morning routine. You knew the Mouseketeers by name: Annette, Cubby, Karen, Bobby. The Mickey Mouse Club theme song is still lodged somewhere in your brain, ready to surface at any moment.

Your toys were built to last generations. Erector Sets with actual metal girders. Lionel trains that ran on their own track around the Christmas tree. Silly Putty that could copy the Sunday comics. Mr. Potato Head—the original version where you stuck plastic parts into real potatoes, because that was apparently fine. Slinky, which you walked down every staircase in the house until it got tangled beyond repair.

At seven, you were crouched under your school desk during duck-and-cover drills, learning that a wooden desk would somehow protect you from nuclear annihilation. Sputnik launched that same year, and suddenly the Soviets were overhead, beeping, watching. Your teachers said we were losing the space race. Your parents said the Communists could strike at any moment. You went outside to play cowboys and Indians anyway.

You ate Campbell's soup straight from the can if Mom wasn't looking. Swanson TV dinners on aluminum trays—salisbury steak with the apple cobbler touching the corn. Jiffy Pop on the stovetop, watching the foil dome expand like magic. Tang for breakfast because astronauts drank it, which made it scientific. Hostess Twinkies in your lunchbox, and nobody worried about expiration dates.

Summer meant catching fireflies in Mason jars, running through the DDT fog when the mosquito truck came (nobody told you not to), and staying outside until the streetlights flickered on. Your mother didn't know where you were for hours at a time, and that was called parenting.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Cinderella was in theaters the year you were born—Disney's first feature since Bambi. Patti Page was singing 'Tennessee Waltz.' Peanuts debuted in seven newspapers, introducing Charlie Brown's quiet despair to a nation that wouldn't understand it for decades. The culture of 1950 was bobby socks and malt shops on the surface, nuclear anxiety underneath.

At five, you heard Elvis Presley on the radio singing 'That's All Right,' and something shifted. By six, he was on Ed Sullivan, but the cameras only showed him from the waist up because his hips were too dangerous. Your parents were horrified. You were transfixed. Rock and roll was the first thing your generation owned that adults didn't control—and they hated that.

You grew up on TV westerns: Gunsmoke, Wagon Train, Have Gun—Will Travel, The Rifleman. Every kid had a cap gun and a cowboy hat. You wanted to be Roy Rogers or Davy Crockett or the Lone Ranger. You sang the theme songs. You knew that good guys wore white hats and bad guys wore black, and the world was that simple.

At eight, you watched Leave It to Beaver premiere and wondered why the Cleavers' house was so much nicer than yours. Father Knows Best taught you that dads had all the answers. Ozzie and Harriet convinced you that every family sang together. None of it matched reality, but you didn't question the gap yet.

Movies were events. At six, you saw The Ten Commandments and thought Charlton Heston actually was Moses. At nine, Ben-Hur and its chariot race. Science fiction meant The Day the Earth Stood Still and Invasion of the Body Snatchers—aliens that were really Communists, conformity that was really the suburbs. You didn't catch the metaphors until later.

Then you turned thirteen. November 22, 1963. You were in school when the announcement came. JFK was dead. You watched Walter Cronkite cry on television. Three months later, the Beatles landed at JFK airport, and four mop-topped British kids made you forget, briefly, that the president had been shot in the head. By fifteen, Dylan went electric at Newport. By seventeen, the Summer of Love. By nineteen, Woodstock. Your generation invented the counterculture, and you were there—or wished you were.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The party line. If you had to explain this to your grandchildren, where would you even start? Multiple families sharing one phone line, picking up the receiver quietly to see if Mrs. Henderson was still gossiping with her sister, waiting your turn to make a call. Privacy was a concept that hadn't been invented yet.

At four, your family probably didn't own a television. By eight, you did—a hulking console with a 12-inch screen that took ninety seconds to warm up. Three channels, and they all signed off at midnight with the national anthem. You adjusted the rabbit ears endlessly, wrapped them in tinfoil, stood in specific spots in the room because somehow that helped the reception. Color TV arrived when you were fourteen, but you didn't own one until you were in your twenties.

At seven, Sputnik crossed the sky, beeping in Russian, and the world changed. You were suddenly enrolled in 'New Math' that your parents couldn't help with because the Soviets were beating us. At eleven, you watched Alan Shepard become the first American in space. At twelve, John Glenn orbited the Earth. At nineteen, Armstrong walked on the moon—July 20, 1969—and you watched it live on that same TV that took ninety seconds to warm up.

You learned to type on a manual typewriter, hitting the keys hard enough to make an impression through the ribbon. Carbon paper for copies. White-Out for mistakes. The hum and clatter of an office typing pool was the soundtrack of professional work. When electric typewriters arrived, they felt luxurious. When word processors arrived in your thirties, they felt like witchcraft.

Computers entered your life in your mid-thirties, beige boxes that ran MS-DOS and required commands you had to memorize. At forty-five, the World Wide Web arrived—dial-up modems, AOL discs in every mailbox, waiting three minutes for a single image to load. You learned email in your late forties, grudgingly. You got a cell phone in your fifties, a smartphone in your sixties. Each step felt like catching a train that was already moving.

You've witnessed more technological change than any generation in human history. Born before TV was common, you've lived to see video calls, artificial intelligence, and computers in every pocket. The world you were born into no longer exists, and the world you inhabit now would be incomprehensible to your parents. You adapted. You always do.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

Korea had already erupted by the time you took your first breath. Your father might have served; 5.7 million Americans did. The war that would later be called 'forgotten' was very much remembered in your household—another conflict, another draft, another set of young men shipped overseas just five years after the last war ended. You were three when the armistice was signed. Too young to remember, old enough to absorb the anxiety.

At four, you watched the Army-McCarthy hearings on television—or rather, your parents watched while you played on the floor. 'Have you no sense of decency?' became a phrase adults repeated. Blacklists and loyalty oaths were real things that affected real people. Your parents were careful about what they said, who they associated with, what books they kept visible. The 1950s conformity wasn't just cultural preference—it was survival.

At four, the Supreme Court ruled in Brown v. Board of Education that segregated schools were unconstitutional. At seven, nine Black students integrated Little Rock Central High School while the National Guard blocked the door. You watched it on television—federal troops escorting teenagers through mobs of screaming white adults. You were learning what your country actually was.

At thirteen, the announcement came—JFK had been shot in Dallas. Your generation's defining moment, the end of postwar innocence. The generational identity section captures what that day meant. What followed: escalating Vietnam, cities burning, a decade of assassinations that proved the fragility you'd just discovered wasn't temporary.

At eighteen, you registered for the draft. Vietnam wasn't theoretical—it was your birthday pulling a number, your friends coming home different or not coming home at all, your choice between service, deferment, protest, or Canada. The war killed 58,220 Americans. Millions of Vietnamese. You knew people on both sides of that number.

At eighteen, Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated. At eighteen, Bobby Kennedy was shot in a hotel kitchen. At eighteen, Chicago police beat protesters at the Democratic Convention while the whole world watched. The year 1968 packed enough trauma for a decade. You lived through it before you could legally drink. At twenty-four, you watched Nixon resign. At thirty-nine, the Berlin Wall fell. At fifty-one, 9/11. At seventy, COVID. History never stopped happening to you.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Here's what nobody tells younger generations: the world you entered at twenty-two wasn't fair either. But the unfairness worked in your favor. You just didn't know it at the time.

You graduated high school in 1968 or college around 1972, stepping into a job market that actually had jobs. Entry-level meant entry-level. A state college cost $400 a semester, and you could pay it with a summer job. The guy in HR didn't require three years of experience for a position called 'trainee.' Companies hired people and kept them—not out of kindness, but because that's how business worked.

The path was visible: get hired, work your way up, get promoted every few years, retire with a pension. Not exciting, but predictable. A single income bought a house, supported a family, put kids through school. The ladder had rungs. Each rung led somewhere. The financial section details how radically that math has changed.

You worked through stagflation in the seventies, watched manufacturing jobs start their long decline, survived the recessions of '81 and '82. By your forties, you were management—either doing the downsizing or worrying about being downsized. 'Corporate loyalty' stopped meaning what your father thought it meant. Jack Welch became a management guru by firing 100,000 people at GE. The contract was breaking, but your generation mostly got out before it shattered.

You learned computers in your mid-thirties, reluctantly. The secretaries who actually knew how to use the new systems suddenly had leverage. You adapted to email in your late forties, to the internet in your fifties. You weren't a digital native, but you weren't a digital refugee either—you learned enough to stay relevant, even if your kids rolled their eyes at your questions.

If you followed the script, you retired with a pension—an actual defined-benefit pension, the kind that guarantees income until you die. Your children have 401(k)s and anxiety. You had health insurance that covered things. You had job security that wasn't an oxymoron. You were the last generation to work in a world where companies believed they owed employees something. You didn't build that world. But you benefited from it.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Your parents remembered the Depression with their bodies—the way scarcity carved itself into muscle memory. They saved string, reused aluminum foil, kept coffee cans full of coins. 'Waste not, want not' wasn't a saying; it was survival strategy. You inherited their caution even as you lived in the most prosperous economy in human history.

The numbers tell a story younger generations struggle to believe. Your first house, purchased around 1976, cost maybe $35,000—roughly 2.5 times your annual salary. You put 10% down. Your monthly mortgage was less than a week's pay. That same house is worth $450,000 now, and you still don't entirely understand how that happened. You just lived there and paid your bills.

You bought stock when stock meant something—shares in companies that made things, employed people, paid dividends. The market was where serious money went. Mutual funds were exotic. By the time 401(k)s replaced pensions in the 1980s, you'd already built a foundation. You contributed because you could, not because you had to. Compound interest did the rest.

At fifty-eight, the 2008 crash hit. You watched your retirement accounts drop 40% in six months. You delayed vacations. You worried. But you didn't lose your house, because you'd paid it off. You didn't lose your job, because you were close enough to retirement that laying you off triggered age discrimination concerns. You recovered. Many of your children's generation did not.

Here's the truth nobody wants to say out loud: you're rich by accident. Not all of you, but statistically, as a cohort. You didn't work harder than your kids. You worked during different economic conditions. Assets appreciated while you held them. Salaries for younger workers stagnated. You got lucky. Luck feels like merit when you're on the right side of it.

Your grandchildren can't afford houses. Your children are still paying student loans in their forties. They see your paid-off mortgage, your pension, your nest egg, and they see math that no longer adds up. The ladder you climbed has been pulled up. Acknowledging that doesn't diminish what you built. But pretending the same financial path is still possible for them? That's where generational tension begins.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1970-1980): Vietnam was still happening when you turned twenty. You either served, got a deferment, protested, or fled—there was no neutral option. You married young by today's standards (average age: 23 for men, 21 for women) because that's what people did. You bought your first house around 1976 for a price that now sounds like a typo. You had your first child. The script was clear: job, marriage, house, kids. You followed it because deviating was barely imaginable.

Your 30s (1980-1990): Reagan. Morning in America. The economy recovered from the malaise of the 1970s, and suddenly it was acceptable to want things again. You were raising kids, climbing corporate ladders, paying mortgages that felt manageable. Your children grew up in the prosperous 1980s, watching you succeed, assuming they'd inherit the same opportunities. They wouldn't.

Your 40s (1990-2000): The Cold War ended when you were thirty-nine. The Berlin Wall came down on live television, and the existential threat you'd lived with since duck-and-cover drills simply... evaporated. Your kids were teenagers or leaving for college. The internet arrived, confusing but clearly important. The 1990s felt like victory—America had won, history was over, your 401(k) was growing. Peak earning years. Peak optimism. It wouldn't last.

Your 50s (2000-2010): You were fifty-one when the towers fell. You watched it happen live, like everyone else. The optimism of the 1990s died that morning. Your kids—if you had them—were draft age for wars that would last twenty years. At fifty-eight, the financial system collapsed. You watched retirement accounts lose 40% of their value. Some of you delayed retirement. Some lost houses. The Depression your parents remembered suddenly felt less distant.

Your 60s (2010-2020): Retirement, if you could afford it. Grandchildren, if your kids could afford to have them. Your parents, if still living, needed care—and you were the generation doing the caring. Medicare, Social Security, the systems you'd paid into your whole life—suddenly everyone was debating whether they'd exist for your kids. You were caught between generations, responsible for both.

Your 70s and beyond (2020+): COVID made your generation the canaries in the coal mine. You were the high-risk population, the nursing home deaths, the reason younger people were supposed to stay home. Some of your friends didn't make it. The isolation was brutal. Now you're seventy-four or older, navigating a world that moves too fast, that values youth, that treats your experience as obsolete. You've outlived so many. That's victory, even when it doesn't feel like it.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Baby Boomers

Baby Boomer. The name itself tells you something—you were the boom, the demographic explosion, the 76 million Americans born between 1946 and 1964. Your parents survived the Depression and won World War II, and they celebrated by having more children than any generation before or since. You were their reward for winning. That's a lot to live up to.

You were going to change everything. You protested Vietnam, fought for civil rights, invented the counterculture, and told anyone over thirty not to trust you. You believed—genuinely believed—that your generation would be different. You'd end war. You'd end poverty. You'd end racism. You were young and righteous and utterly certain.

Then came November 22, 1963. You were thirteen, in school, when the announcement came over the PA system. President Kennedy had been shot in Dallas. You watched your teacher cry. You walked home through streets that were too quiet. That weekend, you saw Jack Ruby shoot Lee Harvey Oswald on live television—the first murder broadcast to a national audience. Something broke that November, and it stayed broken. The innocence of the postwar era ended in a motorcade in Dallas, and your generation grew up in the aftermath.

What happened next is complicated. Some of you stayed true to those ideals. Most of you got jobs, got mortgages, got suburban houses, got comfortable. The radicals became consultants. The hippies became stockbrokers. The revolution became nostalgia. By the time Reagan was elected in 1980, your generation had become the establishment you once vowed to overthrow.

The narrative about your generation is harsh, and some of it is deserved. You pulled the ladder up behind you. You voted for tax cuts that defunded the public goods you'd benefited from. You hollowed out unions, privatized pensions, deregulated finance. The economic mobility you enjoyed? You made it harder for the generations that followed. Not all of you, but enough of you.

But the narrative is also incomplete. You also marched for civil rights when marching got people killed. You were drafted into a war you didn't believe in and came home to a country that blamed you for it. You raised your kids with more emotional awareness than you received. You built the infrastructure—physical and institutional—that subsequent generations use to criticize you.

You're the most politically powerful generation in American history. Every president from Clinton through Biden has been a Boomer. You vote in higher numbers than anyone else. The world is still, for now, arranged around your preferences. That won't last much longer.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Did you ever sit by the phone, waiting for it to ring, because calling someone first meant you liked them more than they liked you? Did you ever rehearse what you'd say, heart pounding, before dialing? Did your mother pick up the extension and refuse to get off?

Courtship in your era was structured. You didn't 'hang out'—you dated. Dinner, movie, maybe parking at the Point afterward. Boys paid. Girls dressed up. Everybody knew the rules, even if nobody wrote them down. Going steady meant his class ring on a chain around your neck. Breaking up meant giving it back. Simple. Brutally simple.

You married young—average age 23 for men, 21 for women in 1970. Divorce was shameful, which meant a lot of unhappy marriages stayed together out of obligation rather than choice. Your generation changed that. By the time your kids were teenagers, divorce was common, sometimes expected. Was that progress? Depends who you ask.

Your generation mainstreamed living together before marriage—'shacking up,' your parents called it, with all the disapproval they could muster. You tried to raise your kids with more freedom than you'd had, more openness about sex, more emotional honesty. How'd that work out? Mixed reviews.

You've buried friends. Maybe a spouse. You've watched the people you grew up with disappear, one by one. Your address book is full of names you can't call anymore. Nobody prepares you for that part—the way your world shrinks as you age, the way loneliness settles in even when you're surrounded by people who love you.

Communication has changed more in your lifetime than in all of human history before it. You went from party lines to smartphones, from handwritten letters to text messages, from calling long-distance once a month (expensive!) to FaceTiming grandchildren who live across the country. You adapted. You didn't have a choice. But sometimes you miss the weight of a handwritten note, the anticipation of a letter in the mailbox, the way silence used to feel like connection instead of absence.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

You survived things. You really did. The Cold War, Vietnam, the assassinations, the social upheaval. You built careers and families during actual hardship. But surviving things doesn't automatically grant wisdom, and the confidence that comes from survival can look like arrogance to people fighting different battles.

The economy you navigated no longer exists, but you talk about it like it does. The advice you offer—work hard, stay loyal, be patient—was true in your era. It describes conditions that no longer exist. When you repeat your playbook, you're not offering guidance—you're describing a world that ended decades ago. Your children and grandchildren don't need to know how you did it. They need you to understand why the same approach won't work for them.

You invented youth culture, and then you refused to stop being the youth. You're still the target demographic. Classic rock stations play your music. Movies reboot your franchises. Politicians court your votes above everyone else's. You've dominated American culture for sixty years, and you don't notice the dominance because it feels like normalcy. Gen X has spent their entire lives waiting for you to get out of the way. Millennials gave up waiting.

The individualism you embraced had costs you didn't see. 'Pull yourself up by your bootstraps' works great when the boots are affordable and the straps are attached. When you deregulated industries, privatized public goods, and voted for tax cuts, you were solving your problems. You created different problems for everyone who came after.

Climate change happened on your watch. Not exclusively—earlier generations started the engines—but you had the information and the power to act, and mostly you didn't. Your grandchildren will inherit that failure. Some of them already blame you. That blame might not be fair, individually, but collectively? The carbon was burned while you controlled the thermostat.

Here's the hardest blind spot: you don't know what you don't know. The same confidence that helped you build careers and raise families makes it hard to admit you might be wrong, might be out of touch, might not understand the world anymore. Listening is harder than advising. Uncertainty is harder than conviction. But your grandchildren don't need another lecture. They need to know you're still learning, too.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

3.6 million Americans were born the same year as you—part of the 76 million classified as Baby Boomers. You're the second-largest generation in American history, outnumbered only by Millennials (and soon, Gen Z). You've held cultural and economic power for so long it feels like gravity—invisible, inevitable, eternal. It isn't.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945): Your parents and older siblings. They grew up in the Depression, fought in World War II, built the postwar suburbs. They trusted institutions—government, corporations, churches. You questioned them. They valued conformity; you invented rebellion as a lifestyle brand. They had smaller families; you had bigger ones. They saved obsessively; you spent more freely. They think you're spoiled. You think they're repressed. Both of you might be right.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): The latchkey kids, the MTV generation, the overlooked middle child of American demographics. They grew up in your shadow and never escaped it. By the time they reached career age, you occupied all the leadership positions. By the time they hit middle age, you still hadn't retired. They're practical, cynical, skeptical of your idealism because they watched idealism curdle into hypocrisy. They'll take over eventually—if there's anything left.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): The generation that can't stop blaming you—and has reasons to. They graduated into the Great Recession, bought houses at peak prices (if at all), carry student debt you never imagined. They entered a workforce you restructured to favor shareholders over workers. When they complain about economic conditions, you hear ingratitude. When you offer advice, they hear condescension. The gap between you isn't about work ethic. It's about math.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Your grandchildren, mostly. They've never known a world before smartphones, before 9/11, before climate change was undeniable. They're anxious in ways you don't fully understand and pragmatic in ways you might respect. They don't expect the system to work for them. They're building around it. They'll either save the world or watch it burn, and they know which outcome is more likely. They need your resources more than your advice—though they won't say it that bluntly.

Your generation controls 52% of American wealth while comprising 21% of the population. This ratio is historically unprecedented. The wealth transfer to younger generations—often called the 'Great Wealth Transfer'—will be the largest in human history. Whether that money gets passed down, taxed, or spent on end-of-life care will shape the economy for decades. No pressure.

year_events: Senator McCarthy began Communist witch hunts
First Diners Club credit card issued
